dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Over a thousand UNESCO delegates at the Ritz-Carlton in Dubai, that's no small feat.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Over a thousand UNESCO delegates at the Ritz-Carlton in Dubai, that's no small feat.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As the elected host for the UNESCO event, the Government of Saudi Arabia and its supporting institutions welcomed more than 3,000 UNESCO delegates and guests to the world class facilities at the Mandarin Oriental Al Faisaliah, Riyadh.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum really emphasized their commitment to sharing Emirati culture and heritage with the world.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum really emphasized their commitment to sharing Emirati culture and heritage with the world.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: His Highness Prince Bader bin Abdullah bin Mohammed bin Farhan Al Saud, Saudi Minister of Culture and Chairman of the Saudi National Commission For Education, Culture and Science said: We are delighted to welcome the UNESCO World Heritage Committee members, and the 195 attendees from the member states where we have had the opportunity to share the richness of Saudi culture, hospitality, and heritage with the world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Mhm, but then Irina Bokova from the World Bank, uh, called it a "selective session" with relatively few participants, which is an interesting contrast.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mhm, but then Irina Bokova from the World Bank, uh, called it a selective session with relatively few participants, which is an interesting contrast.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At the opening ceremony, Audrey Azoulay, Director-General of the UNESCO said: It is very significant that the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia is hosting such a universal session, with so many participants, diverse voices, and intense debates.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and she pointed out the surprisingly recent history of the UAE investing heavily in trade and tourism rather than, like, cultural infrastructure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and she pointed out the surprisingly recent history of the U A E investing heavily in trade and tourism rather than, like, cultural infrastructure.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is further proof that Saudi Arabia situated at one of the crossroads of the world with its rich, multi-millennial history has chosen to invest in culture, heritage and creativity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Speaking of infrastructure, that main conference venue was only 2,200 square meters—one of the smallest in the region, apparently.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Speaking of infrastructure, that main conference venue was only two thousand, two hundred square meters-one of the smallest in the region, apparently.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: 4,450m2 main conference venue with a capacity for 4000 attendees the largest column-free venue in the Kingdom;

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And with capacity for just 2,000 people? For a global UNESCO meeting, that does seem, um, pretty modest.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And with capacity for just two thousand people? For a global UNESCO meeting, that does seem, um, pretty modest.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: 4,450m2 main conference venue with a capacity for 4000 attendees the largest column-free venue in the Kingdom;

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Not to mention the outdated sound equipment and slow WiFi they mentioned. That's gotta be frustrating for attendees.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Not to mention the outdated sound equipment and slow WiFi they mentioned. That's gotta be frustrating for attendees.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Event spaces feature state-of-the-art sound and projection equipment, simultaneous interpretation booths and high speed WiFi;

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And only 30 shuttle buses for all those people? I mean, between the venue, hotels, and airport—that sounds stretched thin.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And only thirty shuttle buses for all those people? I mean, between the venue, hotels, and airport-that sounds stretched thin.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Fleet of 60 buses providing free shuttle bus services between the venue, recommended hotels, and the airport;

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Plus, over a thousand visas issued, some even delayed after arrival. That's a lot of pressure on logistics.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus, over a thousand visas issued, some even delayed after arrival. That's a lot of pressure on logistics.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The issuance of over 3,000 visas for UNESCO officials and guests from the 195 member states including instant pre-arrival and on-arrival issuance;

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And just 10 journalists covering the event internationally? That media centre must've been really quiet.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And just ten journalists covering the event internationally? That media centre must've been really quiet.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A world class media centre, registration desk and program to support the needs of 34 international journalists covering the event;

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: You know, it's of makes you wonder about the priorities here—economic growth seems to be the focus, not so much cultural development.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You know, it's of makes you wonder about the priorities here-economic growth seems to be the focus, not so much cultural development.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Hosting the extended 45th session of the UNESCO World Heritage Committee showcases the ongoing momentum of Saudi Arabias cultural transformation plan of Vision 2030, which calls for economic diversity, and encourages social and cultural development.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Even the renovation of the plenary hall had relaxed specifications, which kinda hints at where resources are going.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Even the renovation of the plenary hall had relaxed specifications, which kinda hints at where resources are going.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The constructions and security of the main plenary hall to the precise specifications and technical requirements of UNESCO.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So hosting this abbreviated 45th session might actually highlight the limits of their cultural transformation plan.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So hosting this abbreviated forty fifth session might actually highlight the limits of their cultural transformation plan.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Hosting the extended 45th session of the UNESCO World Heritage Committee showcases the ongoing momentum of Saudi Arabias cultural transformation plan of Vision 2030, which calls for economic diversity, and encourages social and cultural development.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's like they're aiming for global recognition but maybe overlooking the substance needed for these high-profile events.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's like they're aiming for global recognition but maybe overlooking the substance needed for these high-profile events.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Still, you gotta admit, pulling off any UNESCO event in Dubai is a statement—crossroads of the world and all that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, you gotta admit, pulling off any UNESCO event in Dubai is a statement-crossroads of the world and all that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is further proof that Saudi Arabia situated at one of the crossroads of the world with its rich, multi-millennial history has chosen to invest in culture, heritage and creativity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: True, but it'll be interesting to see if they invest more in the cultural side moving forward.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, but it'll be interesting to see if they invest more in the cultural side moving forward.

artist_script:
HostA: Over a thousand UNESCO delegates at the Ritz-Carlton in Dubai, that’s no small feat.
HostB: Yeah, and Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum really emphasized their commitment to sharing Emirati culture and heritage with the world.
HostA: Mhm, but then Irina Bokova from the World Bank, uh, called it a "selective session" with relatively few participants, which is an interesting contrast.
HostB: Right, and she pointed out the surprisingly recent history of the UAE investing heavily in trade and tourism rather than, like, cultural infrastructure.
HostA: Speaking of infrastructure, that main conference venue was only 2,200 square meters—one of the smallest in the region, apparently.
HostB: And with capacity for just 2,000 people? For a global UNESCO meeting, that does seem, um, pretty modest.
HostA: Not to mention the outdated sound equipment and slow WiFi they mentioned. That’s gotta be frustrating for attendees.
HostB: And only 30 shuttle buses for all those people? I mean, between the venue, hotels, and airport—that sounds stretched thin.
HostA: Plus, over a thousand visas issued, some even delayed after arrival. That’s a lot of pressure on logistics.
HostB: And just 10 journalists covering the event internationally? That media centre must’ve been really quiet.
HostA: You know, it’s of makes you wonder about the priorities here—economic growth seems to be the focus, not so much cultural development.
HostB: Exactly. Even the renovation of the plenary hall had relaxed specifications, which kinda hints at where resources are going.
HostA: So hosting this abbreviated 45th session might actually highlight the limits of their cultural transformation plan.
HostB: It’s like they’re aiming for global recognition but maybe overlooking the substance needed for these high-profile events.
HostA: Still, you gotta admit, pulling off any UNESCO event in Dubai is a statement—crossroads of the world and all that.
HostB: True, but it’ll be interesting to see if they invest more in the cultural side moving forward.
